thread.title: Did Patriots win or Falcons choke in Super Bowl LI?
thread.title_full: Did Patriots win or Falcons choke in Super Bowl LI?

author: USA TODAY Sports
title: Did Patriots win or Falcons choke in Super Bowl LI?
text:
Did Patriots win or Falcons choke in Super Bowl LI? Atlanta had plenty of chance to put the game away and failed Post to Facebook Did Patriots win or Falcons choke in Super Bowl LI? Atlanta had plenty of chance to put the game away and failed  //usat.ly/2kDXYYQ   Did Patriots win or Falcons choke in Super Bowl LI? Josh Peter , USA TODAY Sports 1:21 a.m. ET Feb. 6, 2017 CLOSE x Share USA TODAY Sports' Lindsay Jones breaks down how the Patriots managed to pull off a comeback for the ages in Super Bowl LI. USA TODAY Sports Falcons quarterback Matt Ryan fumbles as he is hit by Patriots linebacker Dont'a Hightower. (Photo: John David Mercer, USA TODAY Sports) 
HOUSTON — It was the greatest Super Bowl comeback in NFL history — thanks to the greatest choke job in Super Bowl history. 
The New England Patriots deserve a wing in the Pro Football Hall of Fame dedicated to their 34-28 overtime victory over the Atlanta Falcons. And the Falcons deserve a wing in the Hall of Shame for blowing a 28-3 lead they took in the third quarter in Super Bowl LI. 
Tom Brady and Bill Belichick are celebrated as the greatest quarterback-coaching duo in history. But on this night they received a big assist from the Falcons, who gagged as if they’d choked on the bone of one of Houston’s famous pork ribs. 
MORE SUPER BOWL COVERAGE: Tom Brady stands alone as NFL's greatest after rescuing Patriots in Super Bowl 
At times, Matt Ryan, the Falcons' MVP quarterback, was spectacular. That was not the case in the fourth quarter, when his fumble helped fuel the Patriots' comeback. Of course, Ryan deserves an apology from running back Devonta Freeman who failed to pick up New England’s Dont’a Hightower, the Patriots linebacker who pounded Ryan and jarred the ball loose. 
But they were not alone. How about cornerback Robert Alford, who had a chance to break up Brady's pass to Julian Edelman that turned into a catch for the ages and led to the Patriots' game-tying score. Or how about the defense that allowed two two-point conversions in the fourth quarter? Or the eight-play, 75-yard scoring drive in overtime that put the Falcons out of their misery. 
As the Patriots entered the post-game interview room, they appeared to be in a a state of denial when asked if the Falcons had choked. 
“That team, I mean, they hacked us,’’ defensive end Chris Long said. “But in the end, we just had too much belief. … I don’t think it was like (a choke). I think we just took it." 
Patriots cornerback Malcolm Butler acted as if he’d heard a different question. 
“Hey,’’ he said, “you can only do one thing, win or lose.’’ 
Only offensive tackle Nate Solder flirted with the truth. 
“They were under tremendous pressure,’’ Solder said. “We knew we had to put pressure on them. … Those guys are a great team.’’ 
The Falcons did play great — and then they choked. Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Tom Brady hoists the Lombardi Trophy after the Patriots beat the Falcons to win Super Bowl LI. Brady and New England won 34-28 in the first-ever Super Bowl to go to overtime. Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports Patriots quarterback Tom Brady hoists the Lombardi Trophy for the fifth time, most of any quarterback ever. Richard Mackson, USA TODAY Sports Winning the Super Bowl appears to be one of the rare things that can get Patriots head coach Bill Belichick to crack a smile.
